editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: The Counterfeit Ievv.
div.p:
IT would fill to much Paper to deſcribe all the Lyes, Forgeries, Hypocriſies, Slights of this miſerable wretch, who Writ himſelfe Joſephus Ben Iſrael. Hebr. Mantu. which part ſo long as he Acted, he did it ſo handſomely, and with ſo much exquiſite hypocriſie, relating the Cuſtomes, Ceremonies, Genealogies of the Jewes, that he eaſily got beyond thoſe who are Novices to thoſe Depths of Satan. He was of an accute wit, an excellent Linguiſt, (ſpoake moſt Languages, and Hebrew perfectly) a ready Schollar, a great Travellar, and came from Hambrough to Newcaſtle, calling himſelfe Horſeley. Before his diſcovery, he could carry himſelfe very ſmoothly, ſute himſelfe to any humour, company, diſcourſe very accurately, by his reddy ſubtile Wit and Tongue he could transforme himſelfe eaſily into what ſhapes he pleaſed, and act any Part; he could command his Eyes, his Countenance, his Tongue; could ſpeake Orthodoxly, Spiritually, Learnedly, Practically. Aske him why he called himſelfe Horſeley? Why; he was a Jew, and feared to be known, in regard ſo many of their Nation have ſuffered in England; and by their Talmud, in danger of Life, any thing is allowed, but Idolatry and Murther. He was than in Judaiſme, but now a Chriſtian. But why came he over into England? Why; He heard of the Fame of the Chriſtians of England above all others; He had ſeen Papiſts, Lutherans, Calveniſts, they were all full of Ceremonies and Traditions; He had converſed with ſome Anabaptiſts in Germany, (and they told him of the Engliſh Chriſtians) but they held Freewill, and ſuch points, and he deſired to worſhip God in the pureſt
way, without mixtures of mens inventions, therefore he came to the people of Hexham, and there (like a childe of the Devill, full of all ſubtilty and guile, extraordinary endued with power and art from Hell, abuſing all the Ordinances of God, and mocking him to his face) he made his Declaration and Confeſſion of Chriſt in the publique Aſſembly before all the People, and afterwards went and was Baptized, ſo joyning himſelfe to that People there, but did not receive the Lords Supper with them, ſomewhat in his Conſcience ſtarlting at that; ſo to avoyd it, he feigned on purpoſe indiſpoſition, diſcontents, as he confeſſed afterwards, all this while uſing in his private Devotion, his Popiſh Prayers to Saint Benedict, Croſſings, &c.

Upon the twentieth Day, the fourth Moneth, he came to Newcaſtle, (being thereunto formerly engaged) to cleare himſelfe of forme particulars, (whereof warning was given to ſome of the Magiſtrates) and the next day appeared with ſome friends boldly before the Magiſtrates, and ſome Miniſters, ready to receive all charges, all which he put off with horrible impudent lying, till one came, who partly knew him, and had lately received a Letter from his Mother at Leith. This came cloſe, and moved his Countenance; when he ſaw he was like to the unmasked, he was ſtrangely ſmitten with feare, and amazement, ready now to confeſſe any thing; and confeſſed he was Maſter Alexander Ramſey his Sonne, a Scottiſh Gentleman,The Inquiſition-houſe, one of the Devils higheſt Courts. was a Papiſt, ſent over by the Inquiſition, (thoſe bloody monſters of men whoſe Helliſh methods in murthering poore Proteſtants is moſt execrable, fit to be abominated in all Common wealths. Turks and Heathens would bluſh at ſuch cruelties) who imployed him (as a notable Mercurized ſpirit, an Embaſſadour extraordinary of theOdi etenim ſeu clauſtra arebi, &c. Devill, Dolis inſtructus, & Arte Pelaſgâ) to promote Diviſions; and ordered him to faine himſelfe a Jew, with other inſtructions; and hearing that the Sect of Anabaptiſts were a very praevailing Sect, his firſt buſineſſe was to be Baptized, and get the Teſtimoniall of a Church; and ſo (after he had blowne up them with Notions about Free-will, &c. which he intended preſently to broach) to make his way through to the Army, where he thought he could doe well enough. An Errant of Hell all along in its methods. In
his perplexed fits he would ſay, Ah, I have a Head fit for any purpoſe; but what ſhall I doe, I am afraid of the Army; but notwithſtanding all this, my heart is not moved more than a ſtone. When he was told he had loving Parents, he profeſſed, he cared nor if he never ſaw theirAn unnatural Son is fitteſt for the Devils vvorſt imployment. Faces. When asked, how he could ſo diſſemble, and be Baptized? He ſaid, He laughed in his Sleeve to ſee how he gull'd thoſe men. He ſaid, He durſt never reade the Goſpel much, for feare of dulling his ſpirit; Devotion was onely for Blockeheads, and dull A State-Ieſuite muſt have no Genius, no fancy for Devotion. Soules. Being asked, What gift in Prayer he had, whether he could. Pray as the Puritans? he ſaid, If he had been put to that he had made mad worke. But what cannot Schollarſhip. Art, Hypocriſie counterfeit? At firſt he complained, he found no remorſe of ſpirit for any thing he had done, but a feare of deſpaire; but being afterwards put in hope to live, he grew more compoſed, and ſaid; The conſideration of the Bloud of Chriſt did quiet his Conſcience. He ſeemes to have a Conſcience full of all ſorts of guilt; one drop of the blood of Chriſt will heale all, and make him repent. If not, ſome notorious ſpectacle of wrath he will prove at one time or other.

Many ſnares and ginns, Providence hath to catch ſuch Vipers, ſuch Incendiaries, though they may long eſcape. Deſperate Heretickes, and ſeducers, that practice onely upon Churches, ought onely to be cut off by the Spirituall Sword of Excommunication, (if they be Members of Churches) and the Temporall Sword doth not at all reach them. True, ſuch as are meerly devout Papiſts, ought not to be harmed or moleſted. But ſuch as come to practice any wayes upon States, Armies, ſent from any of the Seminaties or Colledges of Inquiſition beyond the Seas, with inſtructions from them to poyſon, piſtoll, ſtilletto (and ſuch as have any relation to the wicked, bloody Inquiſition houſe, are fitted for ſuch purpoſes, being uſed to and hardened in blood and cruelties) and have received the holy Oyle and Benediction of the Pone, and his abſolution for the perpetrating of all horred murthers, &c. pro propaganda fide; ſuch Jeſuits and Jeſuited Romaniſts (whoſe Principles are Murthers, Poyſons, &c) that come over, and renouncing their Religion, take up another for State-deſignes onely, and creepe in to get Teſtimonialls, that they may
become Spies in Armies, and worke Diviſions, merit to ſuffer as Traytors, Rebels, Incendiaries of the State.

Omitting thoſe many inferences, that are, and will be made by the Vulgar from this ſtrange Diſcovery, as that, Ergo, all Anabaptiſts are Ieſuits, will turne Papiſts, &c. (a new Doctrine to me) though this Counterfeit confeſſed, that onely the Anabaptiſts or Swinkefeldians, (who hold Free-will indeed) were Burnt, Perſecuted in Germany at this time; whilſt Lutherans, Calveniſts onely, had tolleration, per Publicum bannum Imperatoris. What worſe is Baptiſme, Church-fellow-ſhip, &c. for a Iudas, a Simon Magus, a notorious Hypocrite abuſing them? The Devill will make notable uſe of this, and poſſeſſe the World, that Sheep are Wolves, and fit to be deſtroyed, becauſe Wolves appeare in Sheeps cloarning, one of his old fetches to raiſe up Perſecution, at leaſt Tongue-Perſecution, which hath already too farre pruvailed upon this occaſion: Brethren ſhould not ſtrive. Let us convert it to more holy uſes, and ſee the wonderfull goodneſſe of God, and his eſpeciall care over his poore People in anſwering Prayers, and ſo ſoon diſcovering (as Simon Magus was) this miſcreant, taking this Fox (that intended to have ſpoyled the Vines that hath tender Grapes; and one tricke was, to have blowne up Churches with Notions above Ordinances, if not that, then to try what Free-will could doe, &c.) in his owne net, not ſuffering him to goe any further. Churches as they have their Commiſſion immediately from Chriſt; ſo their Protection alſo: his Banners of Love are over them, their Comforts, their Graces, their Priviledges, their Ordinances. All the Iudaſſes, Annaniaſſes, Simon Maguſſes, Alexanders, Hermogeneſſes, Hymeneuſes; all the poyſon of Heretickes, Peſecution of Magiſtrates, and Rulers were never able to doe the leaſt harme to the Churches of Chriſt. They multiplyed, flouriſhed in deſpight of all the malice of Hell. Never any deſigne the Devill had upon them, but they gained by it; and ſhortly Chriſt will tread Satan under the feet of his Churches; and the Devill. Anti-Chriſt, Hypocrites ſhall pay for all the wrongs they have done Chriſt, his Saints, his Ordinances. Thinke not ſomewhat is befallen, which hath no preſident in the Primitive Churches; thouſands of glorious Hypocrites there are,
though its very rare to finde one ſo groſſe, ſo deſperately profane as this Counterfeit, ſo every way reſembling the Devill. Churches muſt looke for fiery Tryalls, not onely from without, but from within; from Hypocrites, Seducers in their owne boſomes; but they ſhall loſe nothing by all, even ſuch occurrences as theſe; they ſhall ſerve onely to Poliſh them, provoke them to more holineſſe, love, watchfulneſſe, humility. Oh take heed of ſtumbling at the ſtumbling-ſtone; Bleſſed are thoſe that are not offended at Chriſt, his Truths, his Ordinances in theſe dayes. We are like to ſee more of theſe things. Chriſt hath ſore-told us. The Devill will ſute himſelfe into all ſhapes, appear in all formes to undermine Chriſt; he is the Maſter Hypocrite, the Maſter Polititian. Quum pellis leonina non ſufficit, vulpina eſt aſſumenda, Machi. What need had we to beware of men (eſpecially men of Parts, curious Wits, who can turne themſelves into any likeneſſe, eaſily diſguiſing themſelves; we are apt to be taken with Gifts and Parts) ſuſpecting leaſt we be deceived. Churches had need be very wary, circumſpect in theſe times, when looked upon as a prevailing Party, a way to preferment, as Chriſtianity was in Conſtantines Court. There had need be trying, ſearching to purpoſe, ranſacking mens hearts, turning them over and over, before a cloze. Nimia cautela non nocet. ſudden actings in Churches are dangerous. He that ſuſpects not, will beQui cito credit facile fallitu •
deceived; feare every man whom we doe not throughly know: without much warineſſe in theſe dayes, Churches will be filled with Hypocrites; and the moſt glorious Churches will harbour the greateſt deceivers. The World is full ofMelin ote • fil in cord •
Deceivers. The Devill is mightily buſie, extraordinary beſtirrs himſelfe in theſe laſt and perillous dayes. He will raiſe up ſpirits on purpoſe, who ſhall affront, diſgrace, blaſpheme the good wayes of God; his Plots againſt the Saints, the Churches; all the Ordinances thereof are exceeding deep, fairely guilded over. He will ſoment jealouſies, raiſe up ſlanders, back-bitings, cenſurings, judgings, reproachings one another, to divide, to weaken, to deſtroy. He can ſet Saints againſt Saints, Churches againſt Churches, put fire to Churches and Common-wealths. He hath variety of Inſtruments, Engines fit for every worke. The Devill and the Pope make uſe of no
Fooles, they are not for their turne; they chuſe the moſt ſublimated Wits, the choy ceſt pieces of Art and Learning, men compounded of the nimbleſt ſpirits, full fraught with the policy, audacity of the Devill, that have drunke in the very quinteſſcence of Hell; who having loſt all ſence and ſeeling in their Conſciences, in Stew-houſes, Inquiſition-houſes, are on purpoſe trained up to dare to doe anyIllis felix ſeclus, pietas eſt. wickedneſſe, Poyſon Stab. Murther, &c. things that the thoughts of would afright any ſpirit that is but commonly wicked, Cunning Artiſts, deceitfully Workers, who are Ingenioſiſſime nequam, Ingenious Inventers of miſchiefes; Scelerum molitores egregii, free to act all wickedneſſe, (for Jeſuitis Diabolo
que quaelibet audendi conceditur aequa poteſtat) yet can transforme themſelves into an Angel of Light. Alas, how eaſily are poore Lambes and Doves oft deceived before they be aware, by ſuch Foxes, ſawning Simons. Honeſt, ſimple, well-meaning ſoules, (ignari ſcelerum tantorum, artiſ
que Pelaſgae) how eaſily are they circumvented? Therefore Chriſts command is to be Serpents as well as Doves. Rare where both Graces meet, Amare & ſapore. What need had Saints to keep cloſe to Jeſus Chriſt, to Reade, Study the bleſſed Word of God much, to walke cloſe in the order of the Goſpel (as an Army with Banners) which would be as a Wall of Fire and Braſſe againſt Deceivers. What little cauſe of boaſting in Ordinances, Priviledges, when a Devill, a Witch may be under the moſt pretious Ordinances? Church-memberſhip may be without true Saintſhip; men may get into Churches, that ſhall be excluded Heaven at the laſt, with the five Fooliſh Virgins, and carry Baptiſme and all Ordinances to Hell with them, whoſe Flames of all others ſhall be the hotteſt there. Prize grace in every Saint, and love him for his grace meerly, not his Opinion, whatever it be. When Judas is abroad, when the Devill is playing all his prankes, trudging up and downe to deceive; what need had Saints to VVatch and Pray, to watch one over another, exhort one another, continually examining their owne hearts, to finde out the ſophiſtries, ſubtilties that are there; there may be ſeen the greateſt Divels, Jeſuits, Impoſtures in the world acting their parts. The more we feare, ſuſpect our ſelves, others the ſafer from being deceived. Look round about us, within, and without
us, and we ſhall ſee the hypocrite acting every where, in Courts, in Churches, in Gloſets, in Pulpits, in Shops, no place free. Many State-hypocrites, Church-hypocrites, muſt yet be unmasked in England. Bleſſed are poore, humble ſincere ſoules, ſuch onely will he able to endure this day of the Lord, this day of burning that is upon England. Men of all forts, of all Profeſſions will be tryed. None more Devill-like then an hypocrite: he hath his deſignes in all that he doth, but ſo cloſely, cunningly layd, (as Vaux, a Romiſh Emiſſary too, layd his Powder-barrels under the Parliament Houſe) that none can poſſibly diſcerne him, till God himſelfe diſcover him; he can varniſh over the greateſt wickedneſſe, with the greateſt ſhewes of godlineſſe, caſt ſand and duſt in the eyes of all that come neer him, and blinde them. How many ſuch are hugged, kiſſed, embraced in the armes of Saints (as once it may be Phlygellus, Alexander, Philetus, &c. was of holy Paul) who ſhall ere long be turned into the blackeſt Devils in Hell. Oh, who can fadome hearts, who knowes thoſe myſteries of Iniquity, exceeding all thoſe wickedneſſes that are done in the Cloyſters of Monks, the Colledges of Jeſuits, the Conclaves of Popes? A ſingular piece of their wickedneſſe was this counterfeit lew, (a ſelect Commiſſioner of Hell. In utrum
que paratus, ſeu verſare dolos ſau certe occumbere morti.) ſent from the Inquiſition, houſe to try his fidelity (in order to Prieſthood) by ſome notable attempt upon the State, Army, by Diviſion, Intelligence, poyſon, any way (to which his acting at Hexham was but the Introduction) to propagate the Catholique ends; being impowred by the Popes Indulgence, to doe any thing, ſweare any thing, counterfeit any thing, put off, put on any Religion, &c. Oh the blood of bodies, ſoules, that Man of ſinne, is guilty of, (who rejoyceth ſo much to heare of any Martyr, as he calls him. though he be a wicked Rogue, a Blaſphemous wretch, ſuffer for the Catholique cauſe) the Lord Ieſus will judge him ſhortly. The ſtrange diſcovery of this counterfeit, did exceedingly take the hearts of all there preſent, and made them fall down, and adore, and bleſſe God in this great Providence. Greatly would they have rejoyced to ſee any the leaſt true compuction
of ſpirit, ſuch as flowes from ſights of Chriſt, and ſence of pardon. Pray that all thoſe Emiſſaries of Hell may be diſcovered every where: Prayer had a ſtrange influence upon the diſcovery of this Counterfeit; it will yet find out more of thoſe lying ſpirits of Devils, which come forth of the mouth of the Beaſt and the falſe Prophet, (drunke with the blood of Saints and Martyrs of Ieſus) who notwithſtanding all his glorious, ſplended Troope of Cardinalls and Ieſuits (thoſe Cardines Diaboli, thoſe Engines of wickedneſſe dayly attending him) and their boaſting of the Conqueſt of Chinah, (the Atlas Romanae Eccleſia) ſhall be tumbled downe, and made to drinke of the Cup of the wrath of the Lord. Let the Pope uſe all his cunning to divide, diſtract, (as Balaam did) he ſhall not be able to eſcape the Sword of the Lord, which is now drawn, and ſet to his breaſt, and will aſſuredly enter into his bowels. Let him look from his high Prinacle of worldly glory, and ſcorne the Army of England; mock and laugh at the glorious providences of God among us (as the actings of a giddy-headed people) curſe all our proceedings; yet let him know, Chriſt is making great preparations againſt him here in England, and whetting the Arrowes of his indignation, to deſtroy him and his Adherents. Chriſt is undermining all the mountains of his Power and greatneſſe upon which he ſits. Babylon the great ſhall fall, and not one ſtone left upon another of all her ſtately Structure, (her Eccleſiaſticall pompe, and civill Power) which ſhall become a place of Iim & Zim, the abomination of the Earth. In that day, the redeemed of the Lord ſhall rejoyce, the Saints ſhall ſing, yea, even now we are begun to ſing our Hallelujahs, Rev. 19. The Saints of England (a Land of Victories, of Ordinances, of all ſorts of glories) have firſt begun to ſet the Tune of the Songs of Zion, which ſhall be ſung through all Nations, Great and marveilous are thy works, Lord God Almighty, juſt and true are thy wayes, oh King of Saints. Who ſhall not feare thee, O Lord, and glorifie thy Name, for thou onely art holy. For all Nations ſhall come and Worſhip before thee, for thy Iudgement are made manifeſt, Rev. 15.

An Anabaptiſt can never be a Papiſt, nor a Papiſt an Anabaptiſt: He that holds Infant-Baptiſme (as a Papiſt muſt) is no Anabaptiſt. A Papiſt may take up Baptiſme upon a State-deſigne, (as this Counterfeit) but he is a Papiſt ſtill, and holds Infant-Baptiſme. They differ in all Points, Baptiſme, Supper, Singing, Sabbath, Miniſterie, impoſſible to reconcile them.
